docs.snippet: He had his first brush with painting backstage at the Omaha Community Playhouse in 1925, and the artistic talents he demonstrated in designing and painting sets during the next three years were good enough to win him an offer of a scholarship to t...
docs.lead_paragraph: He had his first brush with painting backstage at the Omaha Community Playhouse in 1925, and the artistic talents he demonstrated in designing and painting sets during the next three years were good enough to win him an offer of a scholarship to the Parsons School of Design. But Henry Fonda decided his real stagecraft was acting, so he passed up the scholarship, gave up painting and devoted himself exclusively during the next two decades to perfecting his performing art.

headline.main: Wider Exposure for Henry Fonda, the Artist

byline.original: By Albin Krebs and Robert McG. Thomas

docs.snippet: For a few days each winter the nation's food analysts gather in Florida for an annual ritual - rubbing elbows with industry executives at cocktail parties and luncheons, over tennis games and golf matches. At these conclaves, drinks and camaraderi...
docs.lead_paragraph: For a few days each winter the nation's food analysts gather in Florida for an annual ritual - rubbing elbows with industry executives at cocktail parties and luncheons, over tennis games and golf matches. At these conclaves, drinks and camaraderie flow freely. But today, after Philip L. Smith, executive vice president of the General Foods Corporation, speaks to several dozen food-industry followers, he may be in for some tough questions. Mr. Smith will be confronting an audience that is little impressed with company's recent performance and highly skeptical of its pending acquisition of Oscar Mayer & Company. On Feb. 4, General Foods announced an agreement in principle to buy the Wisconsin processed-meat producer for $464.6 million in cash.

docs.snippet: Long Island University yesterday announced the winners of the 33d annual George Polk Awards in Journalism.  Among the recipients were the editorial board of The New York Times for ''keen perspectives on local, national and world developments'' and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Long Island University yesterday announced the winners of the 33d annual George Polk Awards in Journalism. Among the recipients were the editorial board of The New York Times for ''keen perspectives on local, national and world developments'' and the local staff of The Miami Herald for investigation of police conduct toward the black community of Miami.

headline.main: Polk Journalism Awards; Are Disclosed by L.I.U.

docs.snippet: Near record gasoline supplies promise to slow prices rises at the pump, according to petroleum industry economists. They noted that the record 280 million barrels on hand a year ago helped stabilize gasoline prices last summer. (Page D1.)...
docs.lead_paragraph: Near record gasoline supplies promise to slow prices rises at the pump, according to petroleum industry economists. They noted that the record 280 million barrels on hand a year ago helped stabilize gasoline prices last summer. (Page D1.)

docs.snippet: --------------------------------------------------------------------  Kirk Honeycutt, a freelance writer, frequently reports on the film scene. By KIRK HONEYCUTT LOS ANGELES    About 10 years ago a screenwriter came to Lillian Michelson, a motion ...
docs.lead_paragraph: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kirk Honeycutt, a freelance writer, frequently reports on the film scene. By KIRK HONEYCUTT LOS ANGELES About 10 years ago a screenwriter came to Lillian Michelson, a motion picture research librarian, and asked her to research a movie to take place in contemporary India. It would be a love story, he said, in which a Brahman man, a member of the very highest caste, marries an untouchable woman, from the lowest caste in Hindu society. Mrs. Michelson recalls: ''I told him, 'I haven't done any research on India but I really feel that's totally improbable.' So I spent three weeks in the stacks at UCLA (University of California, Los Angeles), came back and said, 'No way. There are 5,000 subcastes and it's very difficult for one even to go to the next one. But 5,000 - it's as if a human being were to marry a lizard. That's how unthinkable it would be. There is no precedent even in mythology.'

docs.snippet: THE GIRL IN A SWING, by Richard Adams, NAL/Signet, $3.50.) As a British schoolboy, Alan Desland discovers he has clairvoyant powers but chooses to pay them no heed; as a mature man, he takes a trip to Denmark to buy rare porcelain and, after meeti...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE GIRL IN A SWING, by Richard Adams, NAL/Signet, $3.50.) As a British schoolboy, Alan Desland discovers he has clairvoyant powers but chooses to pay them no heed; as a mature man, he takes a trip to Denmark to buy rare porcelain and, after meeting a beguiling girl named Kathe, starts to see and hear strange thing. Our reviewer Robert Kiely called this "a beautiful, haunting novel," its love scenes "lyrical," its ghost scenes "psychologically penetrating." THE WINDSOR STORY, by J. Bryan III and Charles J.V. Murphy. (Dell, $375.) A dual biography of Edward VIII and the twicedivorced woman he thought he could make Britain's Queen. Anthony Howard described it as "the best documented and least inhibited account we are likely to get of the long, lonely years of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor spent in exile."

docs.snippet: When they arrived, there was no San Francisco film industry, only an occasional Hollywood movie using the steep streets and exhilarating skyline of the city as colorful background. ''In 1964,'' says Mr. Korty, who was the first to come, ''in all o...
docs.lead_paragraph: When they arrived, there was no San Francisco film industry, only an occasional Hollywood movie using the steep streets and exhilarating skyline of the city as colorful background. ''In 1964,'' says Mr. Korty, who was the first to come, ''in all of San Francisco there was only one place that had double system projection - film on one track and sound on another. Now there are 20.'' Headquartered in or near San Francisco, they proceeded to make ''The Godfather,'' ''Star Wars,'' ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' ''The Bad News Bears,'' and ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers.'' Through the pressure of their presence and their appetites, there are now film and sound editing facilities at Mr. Coppola's Zoetrope to rival the best in Hollywood; one of the finest special effects companies in the business, Mr. Lucas's 100-employee Industrial Light & Magic; and a music scoring stage that can hold an 80-piece orchestra at Mr. Zaentz's Fantasy Films across the Bay in Berkeley.

headline.main: SAN FRANCISCO Ten years ago, the northern California filmmakers were pioneers.  Francis Coppola, George Lucas, John Korty, Sol Zaentz, Michael Ritchie, and Philip Kaufman had fled from Hollywood - what it entailed or what it symbolized - and were camping out near San Francisco, 400 miles north.
headline.kicker: NORTHERN CALIFORNIA LURES THE MOVIE MAVERICK

docs.snippet: It was 30 years ago that Emlyn Williams, the eminent 75-year-old Welsh actor, playwright and author, first offered a one-man show based on the life of Charles Dickens. Since then, he has taken it all over the world.   On March 13, ''Emlyn Williams...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was 30 years ago that Emlyn Williams, the eminent 75-year-old Welsh actor, playwright and author, first offered a one-man show based on the life of Charles Dickens. Since then, he has taken it all over the world. On March 13, ''Emlyn Williams as Charles Dickens'' will be presented at Montclair State College. The show, basically a series of readings, was performed in New York in January; at the time, it was described as an evening ''of particular interest to anyone with a fondness for Dickens, but also for those who may be skeptical about the ability of a single actor to hold and to captivate an audience.''

headline.main: New Jersey Guide; GOING TO THE DICKENS?

docs.snippet: Dave Winfield, his highly visible winter behind him, stepped into even greater visibility today when he arrived at the Yankees' spring training camp. Visibility wasn't his problem, though. His problems were sneezing and trying to hit the ball out ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dave Winfield, his highly visible winter behind him, stepped into even greater visibility today when he arrived at the Yankees' spring training camp. Visibility wasn't his problem, though. His problems were sneezing and trying to hit the ball out of the batting cage. Winfield eventually stopped sneezing - ''I don't know if it's dust or hay fever or what,'' he said - and eventually he will hit the ball out of the cage with regularity.

headline.main: WINFIELD A HIT - AS A SNEEZER

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A NOTE of warning to that portion of the movie-going public Alfred Hitchcock used to refer to as ''the plausibles'': Stay away from ''Eyewitness,'' a thoroughly delightful but far from plausible mystery melodrama that operates exclusively on high ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A NOTE of warning to that portion of the movie-going public Alfred Hitchcock used to refer to as ''the plausibles'': Stay away from ''Eyewitness,'' a thoroughly delightful but far from plausible mystery melodrama that operates exclusively on high spirits and a no-nonsense intelligence that is never sidetracked by coherence. Even the title is misleading. There is a murder in the movie, but the only eyewitnesses to it are the murderer and his victim, neither of whom is about to talk. Far better to call it ''The Janitor,'' which was the film's initial title, since there is a janitor in the movie who hints that he has information about the murder, though not even he pretends to have been an eyewitness. The title is a red herring, but then ''Eyewitness'' is an ebullient mix of red herrings.
